newsitem.title: CHINA: Honeywell sees heating aiding China sales.
newsitem.headline: Honeywell sees heating aiding China sales.

text.p: Honeywell Inc sees its China sales rising 20 percent this year from last year's $500 million, aided by growing demand for energy-saving technology for home heating, a senior company official said on Thursday.

The U.S.-based company expects rising demand for its control systems as China expands use of so-called district heating, or centralised heating and distribution systems, said Sam Hawkins, Honeywell's Asia Pacific president.
"The use of district heating (in China) has taken off in the last few years," he said.
Many Chinese cities, particularly those north of the Yangtze river, are replacing coal furnaces with centralised heating systems covering large numbers of homes.
This trend has been accelerated by rapid economic growth that has led to the replacement of many smaller dwellings with multi-storey apartment buildings.
China's shift from a centrally planned economy to one based on market principles has also made municipal heating companies more concerned about cutting costs by conserving energy.
Honeywell is looking to sell technology to control boilers and manage the distribution of superheated water used to provide home heating, Hawkins said.
"There are few (system) controls now. If there are controls they are manual," Hawkins said, adding that that meant wide variations in temperature and pressure.
It also often meant that leaks or breaks in the distribution system could go unnoticed for long periods.
Hawkins said Honeywell was working on a project with the Beijing District Heating Co to improve heating services to 20 percent of the capital city's buildings.
That project, which will reduce dependence on coal furnaces and thereby help lower air pollution levels, has World Bank funding.
Other similar projects were being undertaken in the eastern city of Qingdao and the northern city of Tangshan.
Hawkins estimates the overall market in China for this type of control technology will reach $190 million a year by the year 2000.
Honeywell's sales total in the China market also includes control systems for office buildings and hotels as well as process control technology for industry.
